title-group.article-title: Metaplastic Variant of Invasive Micropapillary Breast Carcinoma
title-group.subtitle: A Unique Triple Negative Phenotype

article-meta.aff: 1Georgia Health Sciences University, Augusta, GA, USA
2Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Suash Sharma, Georgia Health Sciences University, 1120 15th Street, Augusta, GA 30912, USA Email: susharma@georgiahealth.edu

abstract.p: Invasive micropapillary carcinomas (IMC) and metaplastic breast carcinoma (MBC) have different clinicopathologic features. This study reports an unusual case of multifocal grade III IMC associated with MBC component in a 35-year-old woman. MBC was vimentin positive, pancytokeratin negative, and showed focal p63 positivity. Immunostains for estrogen and progesterone receptor, and fluorescence in situ hybridization for Her2/neu amplification were negative. All the left axillary lymph nodes dissected were positive for metastatic carcinoma with ductal and IMC patterns, but without metaplastic component. Postmastectomy computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging scans showed metastases to lungs, liver, brain, and vertebrae. The biologic behavior of tumor was in accordance with histology, so that the nodal and distant metastases were testament to the underlying inherently aggressive IMC, whereas large tumor size and triple negativity reflected the features of MBC. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this is the first report of a metaplastic variant of invasive micropapillary breast carcinoma with triple negative phenotype.

body.p: J. L. Petersen in 1993 first described a unique pattern in breast carcinoma.1 It was noted in primary breast carcinoma as well as metastatic tumor emboli in pleural fluid and ascites. This pattern resembled open tubules surrounded by retracted stroma but without endothelial lining. Immunohistochemistry showed abluminal staining with antibody to human milk fat globulins, and electron microscopy confirmed the reversal of cell polarization. The term invasive micropapillary carcinoma (IMC) was first coined by Siriaunkgul and Tavassoli2 to describe these tumors. Currently, IMC is recognized as a rare typically aggressive variant of invasive breast carcinoma, which is distinctive in being typically triple positive but with a poor clinical outcome because of high propensity for lymphatic invasion, nodal and distant metastases.3,4 In contrast, primary metaplastic breast carcinoma (MBC) is a rare specialized entity but with clinicopathologic features different from IMC. MBCs usually present with large tumor size, higher stage at presentation despite less nodal involvement, higher tumor grade, and hormone receptor negativity, requiring aggressive treatment.5,6 We report an unusual case of carcinoma of breast in a 35-year-old woman with ductal, micropapillary, and metaplastic histology with myoepithelial differentiation. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first case report of a metaplastic variant of invasive micropapillary breast carcinoma with triple negative phenotype.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 35-year-old woman with history of left breast mass for few months was detected to have a mass lesion highly suspicious of malignancy on mammography at an outside facility. A biopsy of this mass was performed, which demonstrated poorly differentiated breast carcinoma. Gross examination of the subsequent radical mastectomy specimen revealed 2 dominant tan white firm masses, measuring 7.5 × 7.0 × 7.5 cm and 5.0 × 3.5 × 3.5 cm, involving lower inner quadrant (LIQ), and upper outer quadrant (UOQ) respectively, interconnected by ill-defined induration. Microscopic sections revealed a high-grade infiltrating ductal carcinoma (grade III) with multifocal invasive micropapillary carcinoma (UOQ; Figure 1A), and focal metaplastic carcinoma without any heterologous elements (LIQ; Figure 1B). The high-grade ductal and invasive micropapillary carcinoma components showed immunopositivity for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA; monoclonal; 1:100; Dako, Carpinteria, CA; Figure 2A) and pancytokeratin (monoclonal; 1:100; Dako, Carpinteria, CA; Figure 2B), but were negative for vimentin (monoclonal; 1:100; Dako, Carpinteria, CA) and p63 (monoclonal; 1:50; Dako, Carpinteria, CA). In contrast, the metaplastic carcinoma component showed the reverse pattern with staining for vimentin (Figure 3A), focal nuclear immunopositivity for p63 indicating myoepithelial differentiation (Figure 3B), and focal membranous staining for epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR; Figure 4). Immunostaining for estrogen receptors (ER; monoclonal; 1:50; Dako, Carpinteria, CA) and progesterone receptors (PR; monoclonal; 1:50; Dako, Carpinteria, CA) were negative. Immunohistochemical stains for ki-67 showed a labeling index of 90.5% whereas p53 index was 0.28%. Stain for smooth muscle myosin was negative. Fluorescence in situ hybridization did not show any amplification of Her2/neu (ratio = 1.0:1.0). The overall morphological and immunohistochemical features were consistent with metaplastic carcinoma arising in a background of high-grade invasive micropapillary ductal carcinoma. All the 35 left axillary lymph nodes (35/35) were positive for metastatic carcinoma with ductal and micropapillary features, but without any metaplastic features. Postmastectomy computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging showed widespread metastases to lungs, liver, brain, and lytic vertebral bone lesions involving mainly lower thoracic and lumbar spine, and right femur. She was treated with 2 cycles of Xyotax and Xeloda chemotherapy, on NCCTG protocol 0437, 6 cycles of FEC 100 chemotherapy (5-fluorouracil, epirubicin, and cyclophosphamide), 2 cycles of carboplatin and Taxotere, along with palliative right hip radiation, but with partial response and noted disease progression.

caption.p: (A) Invasive micropapillary ductal carcinoma, with brush border on the abluminal surface (pointer; hematoxylin and eosin [H&E]; ×400). (B) Metaplastic carcinoma component (H&E ×400)

(A) Invasive micropapillary ductal carcinoma showing epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) immunopositivity with abluminal accentuation (EMA ×200). (B) High-grade infiltrating ductal carcinoma showing pankeratin immunopositivity (AE1/AE3 ×200)

(A) Metaplastic carcinoma component showing diffuse vimentin immunopositivity (vimentin ×200). (B) Metaplastic carcinoma component showing foci of p63 immunopositivity indicating myoepithelial differentiation (p63 ×400).
Metaplastic carcinoma component showing membranous immunopositivity for epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR; ×400)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Invasive micropapillary carcinoma is a rare variant of invasive ductal breast carcinoma, constituting about 2% of all invasive breast cancers, and focal micropapillary changes can be present in 3% to 6% of the common types of invasive carcinoma. IMC is distinctive in typically representing the most inherently aggressive form, even when occurring as a focal pattern in other forms of breast carcinoma.3-5,7-12 However, when micropapillary carcinoma is associated to ductal carcinoma in situ the latter is usually well differentiated.13 IMC is morphologically characterized by nests of tumor cells in nonendothelialized retraction spaces and without fibrovascular cores, with “inside-out growth” pattern such that apical morphologic features and EMA positivity are seen on the abluminal, stroma-facing (basal) surface.4,7,8,11,12 IMCs have a high propensity for lymphatic invasion, regional nodal (69% to 95%; often more than 3 nodes) and distant metastases,8 even when the extent of micropapillary growth pattern is limited or focal,7 or in ductal carcinomas exhibiting only partial reverse cell polarity.8,11 Although the exact mechanism of this aggressive behavior is unclear, the altered tumor–stromal interactions along the retraction spaces of IMC are thought to account for increased tumor invasiveness,4,8 as evidenced by the absence of E-cadherin and upregulation of N-cadherin at the interface between the cytoplasmic membrane and the stroma9,10 and, recently reported cytoplasmic expression of p63, possibly contributing to dysregulation of epithelial–myoepithelial balance.12

Metaplastic breast carcinoma is a rare heterogeneous tumor of mammary origin that is morphologically characterized by squamous, cytokeratin positive homologous spindle cell, and/or mesenchymal phenotype with or without a coexistent conventional adenocarcinoma component.6,14 The World Health Organization has classified MBC into pure epithelial type (subclassified as squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma with spindle cell differentiation, and adenosquamous carcinoma including mucoepidermoid carcinoma), and mixed epithelial/mesenchymal types (subclassified into carcinoma with chondroid metaplasia, carcinoma with osseous metaplasia, and carcinosarcoma).6,14 Immunohistochemically, MBC shows a reverse pattern of staining for pancytokeratin (AE1/AE3) and vimentin in carcinomatous and spindle cell component, respectively, as noted in the current case. In addition, positivity for smooth muscle actin, calponin, CD10, and p63 in spindle cells indicate myoepithelial differentiation,6,15,16 which help distinguish MBC from sarcomas such as leiomyosarcoma, angiosarcoma, and liposarcoma.

Clinically, IMCs are usually irregular and ill-defined lobulated masses with high density and microcalcifications on mammograms, a solid irregular and ill-defined hypoechoic mass with frequent axillary nodal involvement on ultrasound, and a multifocal mass on magnetic resonance imaging.3 In contrast, MBCs usually present in individuals older than 50 years with rapidly growing single palpable nodule,5,7 and mammographically as dense round, lobular, or oval noncalcified lesions with circumscribed margins,17,18 which are relatively larger (mean = 3.9 cm) compared with invasive ductal carcinomas (range = 1.2-10 cm) at diagnosis.5,17 An outside mammography in our patient demonstrated an ill-defined mass highly suspicious for malignancy.

Our study highlights 2 unusual findings in IMC: a metaplastic component and triple negative phenotype. In the literature, MBC is known to exhibit a basal/myoepithelial molecular and immunophenotype with expression of EGFR, CK14, CK5/6, and p63 and negativity for ER, PR, and HER2.6,14,19,20 However, IMC has not been shown to exhibit basal-like phenotype.12,21 Yet there are isolated examples of variable mesenchymal differentiation in IMC. One case of IMC in a recent study showed coexpression of CK8/18 (epithelial markers), EMA, and vimentin (mesenchymal marker).12 To the best of our knowledge, our study is the first report of a primary MBC arising in an IMC, with focal p63 and EGFR staining suggesting basal-like features in MBC component. The only other reported case of IMC and myoepithelial carcinoma occurred in different breasts.16

Regarding hormone receptor status, MBC are known to be generally negative for ER, PR, and Her2/neu.5,22 However, there are some reports of positivity for ER and PR ranging from 0% to 17% and HER2/neu expression of 4% to 16%.23 IMCs usually demonstrate a triple positive profile with a high percentage of positivity for ER and PR, and Her2/neu oncoprotein.4,7,24 Exceptions in IMC include a recent report in which 4 cases were found to be negative for the ER/PR/HER2 despite the lack of any basal-like features.12 Our case was triple negative for ER, PR, as well as Her2/neu.

In our study, 100% of the 35 lymph nodes dissected in showed tumor metastasis. Since the lymph nodes mostly showed high-grade ductal and micropapillary areas, we believe that this high rate of metastasis likely reflects the known aggressive biologic potential of IMC as compared with MBC.4,24,25 The axillary lymph node involvement in MBC has been reported to have a lower incidence (6% to 31%) compared with similar sized ductal carcinomas of breast,5,23 being more frequent in carcinosarcoma variant.26,27 The lack of MBC in axillary nodes in our report may be a reflection of its known lower incidence of nodal involvement.5 Alternatively, it may reflect its later evolution as dedifferentiation at the primary site in a preexisting high-grade ductal and invasive micropapillary carcinoma, as proposed recently.6 Furthermore, the location of IMC in UOQ may have facilitated its earlier spread to axillary nodes as compared with MBC in LIQ.

Although the principles of treatment are same as infiltrating ductal carcinoma, both IMC and MBC are treated more aggressively (more often with mastectomy and chemotherapy); IMC because of high frequency of lymph node involvement,4,5 whereas MBC because of higher tumor stage resulting from larger tumor size (despite less nodal involvement), higher tumor grade, and hormone receptor negativity. Recent studies have shown that despite adjuvant chemotherapy, MBC is prone to recurrences, and had a poorer prognosis than triple negative invasive ductal carcinoma, especially in patients with nodal metastasis.23,27 Our case was treated with multiagent chemotherapy but with only partial response and noted disease progression.

In summary, we report an unusual metaplastic variant of invasive micropapillary breast carcinoma with triple negative phenotype. The biologic behavior of tumor was in accordance with the histology, so that the axillary nodal and distant metastases were testament to the underlying inherently aggressive IMC, whereas large tumor size and triple negativity reflected the features of MBC. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first case report of a metaplastic variant of invasive micropapillary breast carcinoma with triple negative phenotype.
